snippet.textDisplay: maybe it was destroyed. But I heard this song, listened to the different renditions/versions of this song including the folk versions. snippet.textDisplay: The songs of the Bauls and their lifestyle influenced a large swath of Bengali culture, but nowhere did it leave its imprint more powerfully than on the work of Rabindranath Tagore, who talked of Bauls in a number of speeches in Europe in the 1930s. An essay based on these was compiled into his English book The Religion of Man.
snippet.textOriginal: The songs of the Bauls and their lifestyle influenced a large swath of Bengali culture, but nowhere did it leave its imprint more powerfully than on the work of Rabindranath Tagore, who talked of Bauls in a number of speeches in Europe in the 1930s. An essay based on these was compiled into his English book The Religion of Man.

snippet.textDisplay: I guess its a dotara, a long-necked fretless lute (while the name literally means “two stringed” it usually has four metal strings) made of the wood of a jackfruit or neem tree. It is one of the instruments used by the bauls

snippet.textDisplay: There was no 'Bangladesh' when Lalon composed the songs. So, Lalon Fakir is also an Indian philosopher, lyricist and composer. The word 'Bangladeshi' would be aplicable only for those issues which are after 1971. লালনগীতি কখনই বাংলাদেশী নয়, বরং ভারতীয়। লালন একদমই বাংলাদেশ নামের স্বাধীন দেশের নাগরিক ছিলেন না, বরং জাতীয়তার দিক দিয়ে তিনি ভারতীয় ছিলেন। কারণ, লালনের সময় বাংলা ছিল ভারতের অঙ্গ। সুতরাং, ১৯৪৭ সালের আগের বাংলাদেশের সবকিছুই ভারতীয় বলে ধরতে হবে।

snippet.textDisplay: Guys this song  is from Assam. Neither from Bangladesh nor from Kolkata. The genre is  Goalpariya Folk Song. Goalpariya songs are a major component of the Assamese folk traditions. With a distinctive style, these folk songs instantly touch the inner chords of listeners with their melody. It was Pratima Barua Pandey – billed the Samraggi of Goalpariya Lokageet – who popularised these folk songs all over Assam with her unique style of rendition, assisted with able instrumentalists.
snippet.textOriginal: Guys this song  is from Assam. Neither from Bangladesh nor from Kolkata. The genre is  Goalpariya Folk Song. Goalpariya songs are a major component of the Assamese folk traditions. With a distinctive style, these folk songs instantly touch the inner chords of listeners with their melody. It was Pratima Barua Pandey – billed the Samraggi of Goalpariya Lokageet – who popularised these folk songs all over Assam with her unique style of rendition, assisted with able instrumentalists.

snippet.textDisplay:
Firstly, I disagree with all those who are saying, since this is a Bangladeshi song, it can not be sang or played by an Indian. Unlike our our worthless sense of national pride, music has no boundaries. But it really befuddled me to see so many Indians using hatred and arrogance as a tool to answer.

Firstly, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh was once together. "No country" was part of another. Secondly, if Ind didn't help, we would still have won our freedom. Probably would have taken 9 months more.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Have you even read Wikipedia before suggesting it? It says "The origin of Bauls is not known exactly, but the word "Baul" has appeared in Bengali texts as old as the 15th century." Bangladesh is NOT India's child. There was no definite country like India before the British came in. We got united as a country only to fight the British. At the end, people decided to separate on the basis of religion. The song belongs to Bengalis, not to Hindus or Muslims.
snippet.textOriginal: Have you even read Wikipedia before suggesting it? এই অসাধারন গানটার সাথে ইংরেজি গানের যে খিচুড়িটা হয়েছে সেটা মোটেও ভালো হয়নি।
সুরের মিল থাকলে না হয় একটা কথা ছিলো।

সুন্দরী কমোলা নাচে। অসাধারন গান। শুধু Aditi Singh Sharma এর পার্টটা ভালো লাগলো না।
এই অসাধারন গানটার সাথে ইংরেজি গানের যে খিচুড়িটা হয়েছে সেটা মোটেও ভালো হয়নি।
সুরের মিল থাকলে না হয় একটা কথা ছিলো।
যাই হোক, ওয়েল ডান।

snippet.textDisplay: Are you blind or deaf ? Did I write anything that really should offend you ? snippet.textDisplay: good lord, this entire ownership blitzkrieg with half-literate rabid communal Hindu Bongs like @Suman Bhowmik, and Wikipedia citing footnote-ers is hilarious. This is a Goalpariya Lokageet thickheads, recorded by the legendary Pratima Barua, which the "Bengali Nation" has heard and appropriated. And FYI, the Goalpara region is in Assam, kinda up away from undivided Bengal! And how does provenance matter? Musicians cull music from everywhere and it's extremely regressive to tag  'em.
snippet.textOriginal: good lord, this entire ownership blitzkrieg with half-literate rabid communal Hindu Bongs like @Suman Bhowmik, and Wikipedia citing footnote-ers is hilarious. snippet.textDisplay:
wikipedia(dot)org/wiki/Culture of Bengal
wikipedia(dot)org/wiki/Culture of West Bengal
wikipedia(dot)org/wiki/Culture of Bangladesh

Bengali culture is shared on both sides of the border. Language, Music, Literature, Food and/or culture as a whole is shared....also the location of the world most populous/fertile delta in the world.

snippet.textDisplay:
Are you forgetting that west bengal exists on the other side of the border?
This song is as much Indian Bengali as that of Bangladesh. Bengali language, culture and music is not different - Remember Bangladesh got its National Anthem from the other side as well?
